content.body:
As mentioned in yesterday's meeting, July's meeting is confirmed as our first hybrid meeting in over two years.  Meaning you can attend in-person if you wish.

The Reflector now has [the July plenary invite,](https://github.com/tc39/Reflector/issues/437) which includes a registration form that anyone who plans to attend in-person **must** complete.

https://github.com/tc39/Reflector/issues/437

content.body:
yulia: shu Out of curiosity do either FF or Chrome need the function part (at least I'm not sure about normal var variables) of https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-web-compat-globaldeclarationinstantiation for web compatibility? JSC at least doesn't do it per our failing of: 

https://test262.report/browse/annexB/language/global-code/block-decl-global-block-scoping.js?engines=chakra%2Cjavascriptcore%2Cspidermonkey%2Cv8%2Cxs%2Cqjs%2Cengine262

content.body: Although maybe that's just more confusing than doing it for all var-like things

content.body: well, no one did the "full lexical scoping" thing for inner functions before ES6
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: well, no one did the "full lexical scoping" thing for inner functions before ES6

content.body: everyone had their own hacks to somehow or other permit functions in blocks in sloppy mode
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: everyone had their own hacks to somehow or other permit functions in blocks in sloppy mode

content.body: nobody scoped them exactly just to the block
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: nobody scoped them exactly just to the block

content.body: Oh, I just mean that the binding inside the function should be the same as the outer block
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Oh, I just mean that the binding inside the function should be the same as the outer block

content.body: wait what does that mean
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: wait what does that mean

content.body: well, kinda, except there's if statements and stuff
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: well, kinda, except there's if statements and stuff

content.body: in ES6 times, the committee liked to apply "intersection semantics" logic, reasoning that if it's not permitted in all browsers, then it won't affect web compatibility. Such a philosophy didn't turn out to result in something that Chrome could ship in all cases.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: in ES6 times, the committee liked to apply "intersection semantics" logic, reasoning that if it's not permitted in all browsers, then it won't affect web compatibility. Such a philosophy didn't turn out to result in something that Chrome could ship in all cases.

content.body: Like AFIACT, f() { f = 123 }; f() print(f); doesn't print 123
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Like AFIACT, f() { f = 123 }; f() print(f); doesn't print 123

content.body: "union semantics" would be unnecessarily strict; web compat reality is messy
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: "union semantics" would be unnecessarily strict; web compat reality is messy

content.body: it doesn't print 123 by my understanding too but what does that example have to do with the annex b lexical function hoisting thing?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: it doesn't print 123 by my understanding too but what does that example have to do with the annex b lexical function hoisting thing?

content.body: It has to do with the fact that annex b creates a new binding inside f
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It has to do with the fact that annex b creates a new binding inside f

content.body: Maybe I linked to the wrong section?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Maybe I linked to the wrong section?

content.body: wait, really?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: wait, really?

content.body: the thing you linked by my understanding only deals with stuff like `{ function f() {} }` or `if (exp) { function f() {} }` etc
content.formatted_body: the thing you linked by my understanding only deals with stuff like { function f() {} } or if (exp) { function f() {} } etc

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: the thing you linked by my understanding only deals with stuff like `{ function f() {} }` or `if (exp) { function f() {} }` etc
the thing you linked by my understanding only deals with stuff like { function f() {} } or if (exp) { function f() {} } etc

content.body: I mean that's why you don't print 123
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I mean that's why you don't print 123

content.body: but your example has no lexically scoped function decl
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: but your example has no lexically scoped function decl

content.body: AFAICT
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: AFAICT

content.body: Sorry
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Sorry

content.body: There should be `{ }` around the declaration of f
content.formatted_body: There should be { } around the declaration of f

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: There should be `{ }` around the declaration of f
There should be { } around the declaration of f

content.body: So, `{ function f() { f = 123 } } f(); console.log(f);`
content.formatted_body: So, { function f() { f = 123 } } f(); console.log(f);

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: So, `{ function f() { f = 123 } } f(); console.log(f);`
So, { function f() { f = 123 } } f(); console.log(f);

content.body: That will print `123` in Safari but `ƒ f() { f = 123 }` in Chrome
content.formatted_body: That will print 123 in Safari but ƒ f() { f = 123 } in Chrome

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: That will print `123` in Safari but `ƒ f() { f = 123 }` in Chrome
That will print 123 in Safari but ƒ f() { f = 123 } in Chrome
